            </XMDual>
            <XMApp>

        <XMath>
          <XMTok font="blackboard" role="UNKNOWN">Z</XMTok>
        </XMath>
      </Math> as soon as it generates <Math mode="inline" tex="{\mathbb{Z}}" text="Z" xml:id="m15">
        <XMath>
          <XMTok font="blackboard" role="UNKNOWN">Z</XMTok>
        </XMath>
      </Math>.
This answers a question of Y. Shalom.
We also obtain a complete characterization of Kazhdan sets in second countable locally compact abelian groups, in the Heisenberg groups, the <Math mode="inline" tex="ax+b" text="a * x + b" xml:id="m16">
        <XMath>
          <XMApp>
            <XMTok meaning="plus" role="ADDOP">+</XMTok>
            <XMApp>
              <XMTok meaning="times" role="MULOP">⁢</XMTok>
              <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">a</XMTok>
              <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">x</XMTok>
            </XMApp>
            <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">b</XMTok>
          </XMApp>
        </XMath>
      </Math> group, and <Math mode="inline" tex="SL_{2}({\mathbb{R}})" text="S * L _ 2 * R" xml:id="m17">
        <XMath>
          <XMApp>
            <XMTok meaning="times" role="MULOP">⁢</XMTok>
            <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">S</XMTok>
            <XMApp>
              <XMTok role="SUBSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post3"/>
              <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">L</XMTok>
              <XMTok fontsize="70%" meaning="2" role="NUMBER">2</XMTok>
            </XMApp>
            <XMDual>
              <XMRef idref="m17.1"/>
              <XMWrap>
                <XMTok role="OPEN" stretchy="false">(</XMTok>
                <XMTok font="blackboard" role="UNKNOWN" xml:id="m17.1">R</XMTok>
                <XMTok role="CLOSE" stretchy="false">)</XMTok>
              </XMWrap>
            </XMDual>
          </XMApp>
        </XMath>
      </Math>.
This answers in particular a question from
[B. Bekka, P. de la Harpe, A. Valette, Kazhdan’s property (T),
Cambridge Univ. Press, 2008].
Lastly, we provide some further applications of Kazhdan sets: we generalize a local rigidity result of Rapinchuk, and give a characterization of Kazhdan sets in terms of strong ergodicity of groups actions; this last result is related to a characterization of Property (T) due to Connes and Weiss.</p>
  </abstract>
  <keywords>Kazhdan sets, topological groups, Property (T),
equidistributed sequences in groups, tensor products of unitary
representations, weakly mixing representations, compact unitary representations,

      </XMath>
    </Math> group, Howe-Moore property, locally rigid representations, strongly ergodic group actions.</keywords>

Kazhdan sets and equidistribution properties]Kazhdan sets in groups and equidistribution properties


<ERROR class="undefined">\subjclass</ERROR>22D10, 22D40, 37A15, 11K069, 43A07, 46M05

<note role="thanks">This work was supported in part by the Labex CEMPI (ANR-11-LABX-0007-01)</note>

  </para>
  <section inlist="toc" labels="LABEL:Section_0" xml:id="S1">
    <tags>

    </tags>
    <title><tag close=" ">1</tag>Introduction</title>
    <para xml:id="S1.p1">
      <p>Property (T) is a rigidity property of topological groups which has been
introduced by Kazhdan in <cite class="ltx_citemacro_cite">[<bibref bibrefs="K" separator="," yyseparator=","/>]</cite> for locally compact groups, and which has
spectacular applications to many fields, such as the study of discrete
subgroups of Lie groups, ergodic theory, operators algebras, random walks,
explicit constructions of expander graphs
and generation of (nearly) uniformly distributed random elements in groups.
We refer the reader to the monograph <cite class="ltx_citemacro_cite">[<bibref bibrefs="BdHV" separator="," yyseparator=","/>]</cite> by Bekka, de la Harpe, and Valette
for a comprehensive presentation of Kazhdan’s Property (T) and its applications (see also <cite class="ltx_citemacro_cite">[<bibref bibrefs="HarpeVal" separator="," yyseparator=","/>]</cite>).
Among amenable locally compact groups, the only ones which have Property
(T) are the compact ones. If <Math mode="inline" tex="K" text="K" xml:id="S1.p1.m1">
          <XMath>
            <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">K</XMTok>
          </XMath>
        </Math> is a local field and <Math mode="inline" tex="n\geq 2" text="n &gt;= 2" xml:id="S1.p1.m2">
          <XMath>
            <XMApp>
              <XMTok meaning="greater-than-or-equals" name="geq" role="RELOP">≥</XMTok>
              <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">n</XMTok>
              <XMTok meaning="2" role="NUMBER">2</XMTok>
            </XMApp>
          </XMath>
        </Math> is an integer, the groups <Math mode="inline" tex="SL_{n}(K)" text="S * L _ n * K" xml:id="S1.p1.m3">
          <XMath>
            <XMApp>
              <XMTok meaning="times" role="MULOP">⁢</XMTok>
              <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">S</XMTok>
              <XMApp>
                <XMTok role="SUBSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post2"/>
                <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">L</XMTok>
                <XMTok font="italic" fontsize="70%" role="UNKNOWN">n</XMTok>
              </XMApp>
              <XMDual>
                <XMRef idref="S1.p1.m3.1"/>
                <XMWrap>
                  <XMTok role="OPEN" stretchy="false">(</XMTok>
                  <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN" xml:id="S1.p1.m3.1">K</XMTok>
                  <XMTok role="CLOSE" stretchy="false">)</XMTok>
                </XMWrap>
              </XMDual>
            </XMApp>
          </XMath>
        </Math>
have Property (T) if and only if <Math mode="inline" tex="n\geq 3" text="n &gt;= 3" xml:id="S1.p1.m4">
          <XMath>
            <XMApp>
              <XMTok meaning="greater-than-or-equals" name="geq" role="RELOP">≥</XMTok>
              <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">n</XMTok>
              <XMTok meaning="3" role="NUMBER">3</XMTok>
            </XMApp>
          </XMath>
        </Math>. A
lattice <Math mode="inline" tex="\Gamma" text="Gamma" xml:id="S1.p1.m5">
          <XMath>
            <XMTok name="Gamma" role="UNKNOWN">Γ</XMTok>
          </XMath>
        </Math> in a locally compact group <Math mode="inline" tex="G" text="G" xml:id="S1.p1.m6">
          <XMath>
            <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">G</XMTok>
          </XMath>
        </Math> has Property (T) if and
only if <Math mode="inline" tex="G" text="G" xml:id="S1.p1.m7">
          <XMath>
            <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">G</XMTok>
          </XMath>
        </Math> has it, so that for instance the groups <Math mode="inline" tex="SL_{n}({\mathbb{Z}})" text="S * L _ n * Z" xml:id="S1.p1.m8">
          <XMath>
            <XMApp>
              <XMTok meaning="times" role="MULOP">⁢</XMTok>
              <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">S</XMTok>
              <XMApp>
                <XMTok role="SUBSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post2"/>
                <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">L</XMTok>
                <XMTok font="italic" fontsize="70%" role="UNKNOWN">n</XMTok>
              </XMApp>
              <XMDual>
                <XMRef idref="S1.p1.m8.1"/>
                <XMWrap>
                  <XMTok role="OPEN" stretchy="false">(</XMTok>
                  <XMTok font="blackboard" role="UNKNOWN" xml:id="S1.p1.m8.1">Z</XMTok>
                  <XMTok role="CLOSE" stretchy="false">)</XMTok>
                </XMWrap>
              </XMDual>
            </XMApp>
          </XMath>
        </Math> have
Property (T) for <Math mode="inline" tex="n\geq 3" text="n &gt;= 3" xml:id="S1.p1.m9">
          <XMath>
            <XMApp>
              <XMTok meaning="greater-than-or-equals" name="geq" role="RELOP">≥</XMTok>
              <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">n</XMTok>
              <XMTok meaning="3" role="NUMBER">3</XMTok>
            </XMApp>
          </XMath>
        </Math>. The group <Math mode="inline" tex="SL_{2}({\mathbb{Z}})" text="S * L _ 2 * Z" xml:id="S1.p1.m10">
          <XMath>
            <XMApp>
              <XMTok meaning="times" role="MULOP">⁢</XMTok>
              <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">S</XMTok>
              <XMApp>
                <XMTok role="SUBSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post2"/>
                <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">L</XMTok>
                <XMTok fontsize="70%" meaning="2" role="NUMBER">2</XMTok>
              </XMApp>
              <XMDual>
                <XMRef idref="S1.p1.m10.1"/>
                <XMWrap>
                  <XMTok role="OPEN" stretchy="false">(</XMTok>
                  <XMTok font="blackboard" role="UNKNOWN" xml:id="S1.p1.m10.1">Z</XMTok>
                  <XMTok role="CLOSE" stretchy="false">)</XMTok>
                </XMWrap>
              </XMDual>
            </XMApp>
          </XMath>
        </Math> does not have Property (T).</p>
    </para>
    <para xml:id="S1.p2">
      <p>Property (T) can be defined as the existence of a Kazhdan pair consisting
of a <text class="ltx_emph" font="italic">compact</text> Kazhdan set and its corresponding Kazhdan constant
(the precise definitions will be given in Section <ref labelref="LABEL:Sec2"/> below). Locally compact groups with Property (T)
are compactly generated. In particular, discrete groups with Property (T) are finitely generated
and it is known (see <cite class="ltx_citemacro_cite">[<bibref bibrefs="BdHV" separator="," yyseparator=","/>, Prop. 1.3.2]</cite>) that the Kazhdan subsets of a discrete group with Property (T) are exactly the generating subsets of the group.
More generally <cite class="ltx_citemacro_cite">[<bibref bibrefs="BdHV" separator="," yyseparator=","/>, Prop. 1.3.2]</cite>, a generating set of a locally compact group which has Property (T) is
<!--  %**** String Line 125 **** -->a Kazhdan set and, conversely, a Kazhdan set which has non-empty interior is necessarily a generating set.
However, the determination of explicit Kazhdan pairs in a group with Property (T) is usually a difficult
task. This natural problem of identifying Kazhdan pairs has been raised by Serre and by de la Harpe and Valette
(see <cite class="ltx_citemacro_cite">[<bibref bibrefs="Burg" separator="," yyseparator=","/>]</cite> and <cite class="ltx_citemacro_cite">[<bibref bibrefs="HarpeVal" separator="," yyseparator=","/>, p. 133]</cite>). Besides these references,
we refer the reader to <cite class="ltx_citemacro_cite">[<bibref bibrefs="BdHV" separator="," yyseparator=","/>, Ch. 4]</cite>,
which presents a method of
Shalom <cite class="ltx_citemacro_cite">[<bibref bibrefs="Sha2" separator="," yyseparator=","/>]</cite> for obtaining Kazhdan pairs for such groups as
<Math mode="inline" tex="SL_{n}({\mathbb{Z}})" text="S * L _ n * Z" xml:id="S1.p2.m1">
          <XMath>
            <XMApp>
              <XMTok meaning="times" role="MULOP">⁢</XMTok>
              <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">S</XMTok>
              <XMApp>
                <XMTok role="SUBSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post2"/>
                <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">L</XMTok>
                <XMTok font="italic" fontsize="70%" role="UNKNOWN">n</XMTok>
              </XMApp>
              <XMDual>
                <XMRef idref="S1.p2.m1.1"/>
                <XMWrap>
                  <XMTok role="OPEN" stretchy="false">(</XMTok>
                  <XMTok font="blackboard" role="UNKNOWN" xml:id="S1.p2.m1.1">Z</XMTok>
                  <XMTok role="CLOSE" stretchy="false">)</XMTok>
                </XMWrap>
              </XMDual>
            </XMApp>
          </XMath>
        </Math>, <Math mode="inline" tex="n\geq 3" text="n &gt;= 3" xml:id="S1.p2.m2">
          <XMath>
            <XMApp>
              <XMTok meaning="greater-than-or-equals" name="geq" role="RELOP">≥</XMTok>
              <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">n</XMTok>
              <XMTok meaning="3" role="NUMBER">3</XMTok>
            </XMApp>
          </XMath>
        </Math>, <cite class="ltx_citemacro_cite">[<bibref bibrefs="Kass1" separator="," yyseparator=","/>]</cite> which gives the exact asymptotic
behaviour, as <Math mode="inline" tex="n" text="n" xml:id="S1.p2.m3">
          <XMath>
            <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">n</XMTok>
          </XMath>
        </Math> goes to infinity, <Math mode="inline" tex="n\geq 3" text="n &gt;= 3" xml:id="S1.p2.m4">
          <XMath>
            <XMApp>
              <XMTok meaning="greater-than-or-equals" name="geq" role="RELOP">≥</XMTok>
              <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">n</XMTok>
              <XMTok meaning="3" role="NUMBER">3</XMTok>
            </XMApp>
          </XMath>
        </Math>, of the Kazhdan constant of the
Kazhdan subset of <Math mode="inline" tex="SL_{n}({\mathbb{Z}})" text="S * L _ n * Z" xml:id="S1.p2.m5">
          <XMath>
            <XMApp>
              <XMTok meaning="times" role="MULOP">⁢</XMTok>
              <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">S</XMTok>
              <XMApp>
                <XMTok role="SUBSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post2"/>
                <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">L</XMTok>
                <XMTok font="italic" fontsize="70%" role="UNKNOWN">n</XMTok>
              </XMApp>
              <XMDual>
                <XMRef idref="S1.p2.m5.1"/>
                <XMWrap>
                  <XMTok role="OPEN" stretchy="false">(</XMTok>
                  <XMTok font="blackboard" role="UNKNOWN" xml:id="S1.p2.m5.1">Z</XMTok>
                  <XMTok role="CLOSE" stretchy="false">)</XMTok>
                </XMWrap>
              </XMDual>
            </XMApp>
          </XMath>
        </Math> consisting of
the elementary matrices, <cite class="ltx_citemacro_cite">[<bibref bibrefs="Zuk" separator="," yyseparator=","/>]</cite> where Kazhdan constants are obtained for
certain discrete groups given by presentations, and <cite class="ltx_citemacro_cite">[<bibref bibrefs="Be" separator="," yyseparator=","/>]</cite> where it is
proved that the unitary group <Math mode="inline" tex="{\mathscr{U}}(H)" text="U * H" xml:id="S1.p2.m6">
          <XMath>
            <XMApp>
              <XMTok meaning="times" role="MULOP">⁢</XMTok>
              <XMTok font="script" role="UNKNOWN">U</XMTok>
              <XMDual>
                <XMRef idref="S1.p2.m6.1"/>
                <XMWrap>
                  <XMTok role="OPEN" stretchy="false">(</XMTok>
                  <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN" xml:id="S1.p2.m6.1">H</XMTok>
                  <XMTok role="CLOSE" stretchy="false">)</XMTok>
                </XMWrap>
              </XMDual>
            </XMApp>
          </XMath>
        </Math> of a separable infinite dimensional
Hilbert space <Math mode="inline" tex="H" text="H" xml:id="S1.p2.m7">
          <XMath>
            <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">H</XMTok>
          </XMath>
        </Math>, equipped with the strong operator topology, has
Property (T), and where explicit finite Kazhdan sets in <Math mode="inline" tex="{\mathscr{U}}(H)" text="U * H" xml:id="S1.p2.m8">
          <XMath>
            <XMApp>
              <XMTok meaning="times" role="MULOP">⁢</XMTok>
              <XMTok font="script" role="UNKNOWN">U</XMTok>
              <XMDual>
                <XMRef idref="S1.p2.m8.1"/>
                <XMWrap>
                  <XMTok role="OPEN" stretchy="false">(</XMTok>
                  <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN" xml:id="S1.p2.m8.1">H</XMTok>
                  <XMTok role="CLOSE" stretchy="false">)</XMTok>
                </XMWrap>
              </XMDual>
            </XMApp>
          </XMath>
        </Math>
are given (in this last example, the group is not locally compact). Notice also that while is not difficult to show that compact groups have Property (T), the
computation of Kazhdan constants is nontrivial even for this class of groups; see for instance
<cite class="ltx_citemacro_cite">[<bibref bibrefs="Neuh" separator="," yyseparator=","/>]</cite> and the references therein.</p>
    </para>
    <para xml:id="S1.p3">
      <p>Even if a topological group does not have Property (T) it is still interesting to
investigate some natural weaker rigidity properties of the group. See
for example <cite class="ltx_citemacro_cite">[<bibref bibrefs="LZ" separator="," yyseparator=","/>]</cite>, or <cite class="ltx_citemacro_cite">[<bibref bibrefs="Lubo94" separator="," yyseparator=","/>]</cite> which introduces the weaker Property (<Math mode="inline" tex="\tau" text="tau" xml:id="S1.p3.m1">
          <XMath>
            <XMTok font="italic" name="tau" role="UNKNOWN">τ</XMTok>
          </XMath>
        </Math>). Property (<Math mode="inline" tex="\tau" text="tau" xml:id="S1.p3.m2">
          <XMath>
            <XMTok font="italic" name="tau" role="UNKNOWN">τ</XMTok>
          </XMath>
        </Math>) is for instance sufficient for applications to expander graphs.
It is also an interesting and difficult problem, mentioned in <cite class="ltx_citemacro_cite">[<bibref bibrefs="BdHV" separator="," yyseparator=","/>, Sec. 7.12]</cite> to exhibit “small”
Kazhdan subsets of groups which do not have Property (T) and, more generally, to determine the class of all Kazhdan subsets of such groups.</p>
    </para>
<!--  %**** String Line 150 **** -->    <para xml:id="S1.p4">
      <p>The main motivations for the present paper are the following two questions of <cite class="ltx_citemacro_cite">[<bibref bibrefs="BdHV" separator="," yyseparator=","/>, Sec. 7.12]</cite>. The first one is due to Y. Shalom:</p>
    </para>
    <theorem class="ltx_theorem_question" inlist="thm theorem:question" labels="LABEL:Question_0" xml:id="S1.Thmtheorem1">
      <tags>
        <tag>Question 1.1</tag>

        <tag role="refnum">1.1</tag>
        <tag role="typerefnum">Question 1.1</tag>
      </tags>
      <title class="ltx_runin"><tag><text font="bold">Question 1.1</text></tag></title>
      <para xml:id="S1.Thmtheorem1.p1">
        <p><cite class="ltx_citemacro_cite"><text font="italic">[</text><bibref bibrefs="BdHV" separator="," yyseparator=","/><text font="italic">, Sec. 7.12]</text></cite><text font="italic">
“The question of knowing if a subset <Math mode="inline" tex="{Q}" text="Q" xml:id="S1.Thmtheorem1.p1.m1">
              <XMath>
                <XMTok role="UNKNOWN">Q</XMTok>
              </XMath>

              <XMath>
                <XMTok font="blackboard upright" role="UNKNOWN">Z</XMTok>
              </XMath>
            </Math> is a Kazhdan set is
possibly related to the equidistribution of the sequence <Math mode="inline" tex="(e^{2i\pi n\theta})_{n\,\in Q}" text="(e ^ (2 * i * pi * n * theta)) _ (n element-of Q)" xml:id="S1.Thmtheorem1.p1.m3">

                        <XMTok role="UNKNOWN">e</XMTok>
                        <XMApp>
                          <XMTok meaning="times" role="MULOP">⁢</XMTok>

                      </XMApp>
                      <XMTok font="upright" role="CLOSE" stretchy="false">)</XMTok>
                    </XMWrap>
                  </XMDual>
                  <XMApp>
                    <XMTok font="upright" fontsize="70%" meaning="element-of" name="in" role="RELOP">∈</XMTok>

                    <XMTok fontsize="70%" role="UNKNOWN">Q</XMTok>
                  </XMApp>
                </XMApp>
              </XMath>
            </Math> for <Math mode="inline" tex="\theta" text="theta" xml:id="S1.Thmtheorem1.p1.m4">
              <XMath>
                <XMTok name="theta" role="UNKNOWN">θ</XMTok>
              </XMath>
            </Math> irrational, in the sense of Weyl.”</text></p>
      </para>
    </theorem>
    <para xml:id="S1.p5">
      <p>It is not difficult to see that if <Math mode="inline" tex="p\geq 2" text="p &gt;= 2" xml:id="S1.p5.m1">
          <XMath>

        </Math>.

          </XMath>
        </Math>, while
there are irrational numbers <Math mode="inline" tex="\theta" text="theta" xml:id="S1.p5.m9">

          <XMath>
            <XMTok font="blackboard" role="UNKNOWN">T</XMTok>
          </XMath>

So Question
<ref labelref="LABEL:Question_0"/> may be rephrased as follows:</p>
    </para>

              <XMath>

<!--  %**** String Line 175 **** -->    <para xml:id="S1.p6">
      <p>The second question of <cite class="ltx_citemacro_cite">[<bibref bibrefs="BdHV" separator="," yyseparator=","/>, Sec. 7.12]</cite> runs as follows:</p>
    </para>
    <theorem class="ltx_theorem_question" inlist="thm theorem:question" labels="LABEL:Question_00" xml:id="S1.Thmtheorem3">
      <tags>
        <tag>Question 1.3</tag>
        <tag role="autoref">1.3</tag>
        <tag role="refnum">1.3</tag>
        <tag role="typerefnum">Question 1.3</tag>
      </tags>
      <title class="ltx_runin"><tag><text font="bold">Question 1.3</text></tag></title>
      <para xml:id="S1.Thmtheorem3.p1">
        <p><cite class="ltx_citemacro_cite"><text font="italic">[</text><bibref bibrefs="BdHV" separator="," yyseparator=","/><text font="italic">, Sec. 7.12]</text></cite><text font="italic">
“More generally, what are the Kazhdan subsets
of <Math mode="inline" tex="{\mathbb{Z}}^{k}" text="Z ^ k" xml:id="S1.Thmtheorem3.p1.m1">

                </XMApp>
              </XMath>
            </Math>, the Heisenberg group, or other infinite amenable groups?”</text></p>
      </para>
    </theorem>
    <para xml:id="S1.p7">
      <p>There are several possible ways of defining uniformly distributed sequences in <Math mode="inline" tex="{\mathbb{Z}}" text="Z" xml:id="S1.p7.m1">
          <XMath>
            <XMTok font="blackboard" role="UNKNOWN">Z</XMTok>
          </XMath>
        </Math> and, more generally, in locally compact groups.
We refer the reader to the books <cite class="ltx_citemacro_cite">[<bibref bibrefs="KuiNied" separator="," yyseparator=","/>]</cite> and <cite class="ltx_citemacro_cite">[<bibref bibrefs="DT" separator="," yyseparator=","/>]</cite>, and to the papers by Veech <cite class="ltx_citemacro_cite">[<bibref bibrefs="V1" separator="," yyseparator=","/>]</cite>, <cite class="ltx_citemacro_cite">[<bibref bibrefs="V2" separator="," yyseparator=","/>]</cite> and Losert and Rindler <cite class="ltx_citemacro_cite">[<bibref bibrefs="LR" separator="," yyseparator=","/>]</cite>, <cite class="ltx_citemacro_cite">[<bibref bibrefs="GLR" separator="," yyseparator=","/>]</cite> for a presentation of various notions of uniform distribution in general locally compact groups. If <Math mode="inline" tex="(g_{k})_{k\geq 1}" text="g _ k _ (k &gt;= 1)" xml:id="S1.p7.m2">
          <XMath>
            <XMApp>
              <XMTok role="SUBSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post2"/>
              <XMDual>
                <XMRef idref="S1.p7.m2.1"/>
                <XMWrap>
                  <XMTok role="OPEN" stretchy="false">(</XMTok>
                  <XMApp xml:id="S1.p7.m2.1">
                    <XMTok role="SUBSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post2"/>
                    <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">g</XMTok>
                    <XMTok font="italic" fontsize="70%" role="UNKNOWN">k</XMTok>
                  </XMApp>
                  <XMTok role="CLOSE" stretchy="false">)</XMTok>
                </XMWrap>
              </XMDual>
              <XMApp>
                <XMTok fontsize="70%" meaning="greater-than-or-equals" name="geq" role="RELOP">≥</XMTok>
                <XMTok font="italic" fontsize="70%" role="UNKNOWN">k</XMTok>
                <XMTok fontsize="70%" meaning="1" role="NUMBER">1</XMTok>
              </XMApp>
            </XMApp>
          </XMath>
        </Math> is a sequence of elements in a locally compact group <Math mode="inline" tex="G" text="G" xml:id="S1.p7.m3">
          <XMath>
            <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">G</XMTok>
          </XMath>
        </Math>, uniform distribution of <Math mode="inline" tex="(g_{k})_{k\geq 1}" text="g _ k _ (k &gt;= 1)" xml:id="S1.p7.m4">
          <XMath>
            <XMApp>
              <XMTok role="SUBSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post2"/>
              <XMDual>
                <XMRef idref="S1.p7.m4.1"/>
                <XMWrap>
                  <XMTok role="OPEN" stretchy="false">(</XMTok>
                  <XMApp xml:id="S1.p7.m4.1">
                    <XMTok role="SUBSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post2"/>
                    <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">g</XMTok>
                    <XMTok font="italic" fontsize="70%" role="UNKNOWN">k</XMTok>
                  </XMApp>
                  <XMTok role="CLOSE" stretchy="false">)</XMTok>
                </XMWrap>
              </XMDual>
              <XMApp>
                <XMTok fontsize="70%" meaning="greater-than-or-equals" name="geq" role="RELOP">≥</XMTok>
                <XMTok font="italic" fontsize="70%" role="UNKNOWN">k</XMTok>
                <XMTok fontsize="70%" meaning="1" role="NUMBER">1</XMTok>
              </XMApp>
            </XMApp>
          </XMath>
        </Math> in any of these senses requires a certain form of convergence, as <Math mode="inline" tex="N" text="N" xml:id="S1.p7.m5">
          <XMath>
            <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">N</XMTok>
          </XMath>
        </Math> tends to infinity, of the means</p>
      <equation labels="LABEL:means" xml:id="S1.E1">
        <tags>
          <tag>(1)</tag>
          <tag role="autoref">Equation 1</tag>
          <tag role="refnum">1</tag>
        </tags>
        <Math mode="display" tex="\dfrac{1}{N}{\displaystyle}\sum_{k=1}^{N}\pi(g_{k})" text="(1 / N) * ((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ N)@(pi * g _ k)" xml:id="S1.E1.m1">
          <XMath>
            <XMApp>
              <XMTok meaning="times" role="MULOP">⁢</XMTok>
              <XMApp>
                <XMTok mathstyle="display" meaning="divide" role="FRACOP"/>
                <XMTok meaning="1" role="NUMBER">1</XMTok>
                <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">N</XMTok>
              </XMApp>
              <XMApp>
                <XMApp scriptpos="mid">
                  <XMTok role="SUPERSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="mid2"/>
                  <XMApp scriptpos="mid">
                    <XMTok role="SUBSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="mid2"/>
                    <XMTok mathstyle="display" meaning="sum" role="SUMOP" scriptpos="mid">∑</XMTok>
                    <XMApp>
                      <XMTok fontsize="70%" meaning="equals" role="RELOP">=</XMTok>
                      <XMTok font="italic" fontsize="70%" role="UNKNOWN">k</XMTok>
                      <XMTok fontsize="70%" meaning="1" role="NUMBER">1</XMTok>
                    </XMApp>
                  </XMApp>
                  <XMTok font="italic" fontsize="70%" role="UNKNOWN">N</XMTok>
                </XMApp>
                <XMApp>
                  <XMTok meaning="times" role="MULOP">⁢</XMTok>
                  <XMTok font="italic" name="pi" role="UNKNOWN">π</XMTok>
                  <XMDual>
                    <XMRef idref="S1.E1.m1.1"/>
                    <XMWrap>
                      <XMTok role="OPEN" stretchy="false">(</XMTok>
                      <XMApp xml:id="S1.E1.m1.1">
                        <XMTok role="SUBSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post2"/>
                        <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">g</XMTok>
                        <XMTok font="italic" fontsize="70%" role="UNKNOWN">k</XMTok>
                      </XMApp>
                      <XMTok role="CLOSE" stretchy="false">)</XMTok>
                    </XMWrap>
                  </XMDual>
                </XMApp>
              </XMApp>
            </XMApp>
          </XMath>
        </Math>
      </equation>
      <p>to the orthogonal projection <Math mode="inline" tex="P_{\pi}" text="P _ pi" xml:id="S1.p7.m6">
          <XMath>
            <XMApp>
              <XMTok role="SUBSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post2"/>
              <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">P</XMTok>
              <XMTok font="italic" fontsize="70%" name="pi" role="UNKNOWN">π</XMTok>
            </XMApp>
          </XMath>
        </Math> on the subspace of invariant vectors for <Math mode="inline" tex="\pi" text="pi" xml:id="S1.p7.m7">
          <XMath>
            <XMTok font="italic" name="pi" role="UNKNOWN">π</XMTok>
          </XMath>
        </Math>, for a certain class of unitary representations <Math mode="inline" tex="\pi" text="pi" xml:id="S1.p7.m8">
          <XMath>
            <XMTok font="italic" name="pi" role="UNKNOWN">π</XMTok>
          </XMath>
        </Math> of <Math mode="inline" tex="G" text="G" xml:id="S1.p7.m9">
          <XMath>
            <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">G</XMTok>
          </XMath>
        </Math>.
Veech <cite class="ltx_citemacro_cite">[<bibref bibrefs="V1" separator="," yyseparator=","/>]</cite>, <cite class="ltx_citemacro_cite">[<bibref bibrefs="V2" separator="," yyseparator=","/>]</cite> calls <Math mode="inline" tex="(g_{k})_{k\geq 1}" text="g _ k _ (k &gt;= 1)" xml:id="S1.p7.m10">
          <XMath>
            <XMApp>
              <XMTok role="SUBSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post2"/>
              <XMDual>
                <XMRef idref="S1.p7.m10.1"/>
                <XMWrap>
                  <XMTok role="OPEN" stretchy="false">(</XMTok>
                  <XMApp xml:id="S1.p7.m10.1">
                    <XMTok role="SUBSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post2"/>
                    <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">g</XMTok>
                    <XMTok font="italic" fontsize="70%" role="UNKNOWN">k</XMTok>
                  </XMApp>
                  <XMTok role="CLOSE" stretchy="false">)</XMTok>
                </XMWrap>
              </XMDual>
              <XMApp>
                <XMTok fontsize="70%" meaning="greater-than-or-equals" name="geq" role="RELOP">≥</XMTok>
                <XMTok font="italic" fontsize="70%" role="UNKNOWN">k</XMTok>
                <XMTok fontsize="70%" meaning="1" role="NUMBER">1</XMTok>
              </XMApp>
            </XMApp>
          </XMath>
        </Math> uniformly distributed in <Math mode="inline" tex="G" text="G" xml:id="S1.p7.m11">
          <XMath>
            <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">G</XMTok>
          </XMath>
        </Math> if the convergence of the means (<ref labelref="LABEL:means"/>) holds in the weak operator topology for all unitary representations of <Math mode="inline" tex="G" text="G" xml:id="S1.p7.m12">
          <XMath>
            <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">G</XMTok>
          </XMath>
        </Math> (or, equivalently, for all irreducible unitary representations of <Math mode="inline" tex="G" text="G" xml:id="S1.p7.m13">
          <XMath>
            <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">G</XMTok>
          </XMath>
        </Math>, provided <Math mode="inline" tex="G" text="G" xml:id="S1.p7.m14">
          <XMath>
            <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">G</XMTok>
          </XMath>
        </Math> is supposed to be second countable). Unitary uniform distribution in the sense of Losert and Rindler <cite class="ltx_citemacro_cite">[<bibref bibrefs="LR" separator="," yyseparator=","/>]</cite>, <cite class="ltx_citemacro_cite">[<bibref bibrefs="GLR" separator="," yyseparator=","/>]</cite> requires the convergence in the strong operator topology of the means (<ref labelref="LABEL:means"/>) for all irreducible unitary representations of the group, while Hartman uniform distribution only requires convergence in the strong operator topology for all finite dimensional unitary representations. All these notions coincide when <Math mode="inline" tex="G" text="G" xml:id="S1.p7.m15">
          <XMath>
            <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">G</XMTok>
          </XMath>
        </Math> is a Moore group, i.e. when all irreducible unitary representations of the group are finite dimensional. It is essentially obvious that
if <Math mode="inline" tex="(g_{k})_{k\geq 1}" text="g _ k _ (k &gt;= 1)" xml:id="S1.p7.m16">
          <XMath>
            <XMApp>
              <XMTok role="SUBSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post2"/>
              <XMDual>
                <XMRef idref="S1.p7.m16.1"/>
                <XMWrap>
                  <XMTok role="OPEN" stretchy="false">(</XMTok>
                  <XMApp xml:id="S1.p7.m16.1">
                    <XMTok role="SUBSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post2"/>
                    <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">g</XMTok>
                    <XMTok font="italic" fontsize="70%" role="UNKNOWN">k</XMTok>
                  </XMApp>
                  <XMTok role="CLOSE" stretchy="false">)</XMTok>
                </XMWrap>
              </XMDual>
              <XMApp>
                <XMTok fontsize="70%" meaning="greater-than-or-equals" name="geq" role="RELOP">≥</XMTok>
                <XMTok font="italic" fontsize="70%" role="UNKNOWN">k</XMTok>
                <XMTok fontsize="70%" meaning="1" role="NUMBER">1</XMTok>
              </XMApp>
            </XMApp>
          </XMath>
        </Math> is a sequence of elements of a locally compact group <Math mode="inline" tex="G" text="G" xml:id="S1.p7.m17">
          <XMath>
            <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">G</XMTok>
          </XMath>
        </Math> which is uniformly distributed in <Math mode="inline" tex="G" text="G" xml:id="S1.p7.m18">
          <XMath>
            <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">G</XMTok>
          </XMath>
        </Math> in any of these senses, the set <Math mode="inline" tex="\{g_{k}\;;\;k\geq 1\}" text="set@(list@(g _ k, k) &gt;= 1)" xml:id="S1.p7.m19">
          <XMath>
            <XMDual>
              <XMApp>
                <XMTok meaning="set"/>
                <XMRef idref="S1.p7.m19.2"/>
              </XMApp>
              <XMWrap>
                <XMTok role="OPEN" stretchy="false">{</XMTok>
                <XMApp xml:id="S1.p7.m19.2">
                  <XMTok meaning="greater-than-or-equals" name="geq" role="RELOP">≥</XMTok>
                  <XMDual>
                    <XMApp>
                      <XMTok meaning="list"/>
                      <XMRef idref="S1.p7.m19.2.1"/>
                      <XMRef idref="S1.p7.m19.1"/>
                    </XMApp>
                    <XMWrap>
                      <XMApp rpadding="2.8pt" xml:id="S1.p7.m19.2.1">
                        <XMTok role="SUBSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post2"/>
                        <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">g</XMTok>
                        <XMTok font="italic" fontsize="70%" role="UNKNOWN">k</XMTok>
                      </XMApp>
                      <XMTok role="PUNCT" rpadding="2.8pt">;</XMTok>
                      <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN" xml:id="S1.p7.m19.1">k</XMTok>
                    </XMWrap>
                  </XMDual>
                  <XMTok meaning="1" role="NUMBER">1</XMTok>
                </XMApp>
                <XMTok role="CLOSE" stretchy="false">}</XMTok>
              </XMWrap>
            </XMDual>
          </XMath>
        </Math> is a Kazhdan set in <Math mode="inline" tex="G" text="G" xml:id="S1.p7.m20">
          <XMath>
            <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">G</XMTok>
          </XMath>
        </Math>.</p>
    </para>
    <para xml:id="S1.p8">
      <p>In the case of the group <Math mode="inline" tex="{\mathbb{Z}}" text="Z" xml:id="S1.p8.m1">
          <XMath>
            <XMTok font="blackboard" role="UNKNOWN">Z</XMTok>
          </XMath>
        </Math>, the classic Weyl criterion <cite class="ltx_citemacro_cite">[<bibref bibrefs="KuiNied" separator="," yyseparator=","/>]</cite> implies that a sequence <Math mode="inline" tex="(n_{k})_{k\geq 1}" text="n _ k _ (k &gt;= 1)" xml:id="S1.p8.m2">
          <XMath>
            <XMApp>
              <XMTok role="SUBSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post2"/>
              <XMDual>
                <XMRef idref="S1.p8.m2.1"/>
                <XMWrap>
                  <XMTok role="OPEN" stretchy="false">(</XMTok>
                  <XMApp xml:id="S1.p8.m2.1">
                    <XMTok role="SUBSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post2"/>
                    <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">n</XMTok>
                    <XMTok font="italic" fontsize="70%" role="UNKNOWN">k</XMTok>
                  </XMApp>
                  <XMTok role="CLOSE" stretchy="false">)</XMTok>
                </XMWrap>
              </XMDual>
              <XMApp>
                <XMTok fontsize="70%" meaning="greater-than-or-equals" name="geq" role="RELOP">≥</XMTok>
                <XMTok font="italic" fontsize="70%" role="UNKNOWN">k</XMTok>
                <XMTok fontsize="70%" meaning="1" role="NUMBER">1</XMTok>
              </XMApp>
            </XMApp>
          </XMath>
        </Math> of
elements of <Math mode="inline" tex="{\mathbb{Z}}" text="Z" xml:id="S1.p8.m3">
          <XMath>
            <XMTok font="blackboard" role="UNKNOWN">Z</XMTok>
          </XMath>
        </Math> is unitarily or Hartman uniformly distributed in <Math mode="inline" tex="{\mathbb{Z}}" text="Z" xml:id="S1.p8.m4">
          <XMath>
            <XMTok font="blackboard" role="UNKNOWN">Z</XMTok>
          </XMath>
        </Math> if and only if the sequence
<Math mode="inline" tex="(e^{2i\pi n_{k}\theta})_{k\,\geq 1}" text="(e ^ (2 * i * pi * n _ k * theta)) _ (k &gt;= 1)" xml:id="S1.p8.m5">
          <XMath>
            <XMApp>
              <XMTok role="SUBSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post2"/>
              <XMDual>
                <XMRef idref="S1.p8.m5.1"/>
                <XMWrap>
                  <XMTok role="OPEN" stretchy="false">(</XMTok>
                  <XMApp xml:id="S1.p8.m5.1">
                    <XMTok role="SUPERSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post2"/>
                    <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">e</XMTok>
                    <XMApp>
                      <XMTok meaning="times" role="MULOP">⁢</XMTok>
                      <XMTok fontsize="70%" meaning="2" role="NUMBER">2</XMTok>
                      <XMTok font="italic" fontsize="70%" role="UNKNOWN">i</XMTok>
                      <XMTok font="italic" fontsize="70%" name="pi" role="UNKNOWN">π</XMTok>
                      <XMApp>
                        <XMTok role="SUBSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post3"/>
                        <XMTok font="italic" fontsize="70%" role="UNKNOWN">n</XMTok>
                        <XMTok font="italic" fontsize="50%" role="UNKNOWN">k</XMTok>
                      </XMApp>
                      <XMTok font="italic" fontsize="70%" name="theta" role="UNKNOWN">θ</XMTok>
                    </XMApp>
                  </XMApp>
                  <XMTok role="CLOSE" stretchy="false">)</XMTok>
                </XMWrap>
              </XMDual>
              <XMApp>
                <XMTok fontsize="70%" meaning="greater-than-or-equals" name="geq" role="RELOP">≥</XMTok>
                <XMTok font="italic" fontsize="70%" role="UNKNOWN" rpadding="1.7pt">k</XMTok>
                <XMTok fontsize="70%" meaning="1" role="NUMBER">1</XMTok>
              </XMApp>
            </XMApp>
          </XMath>
        </Math> is uniformly distributed in
<Math mode="inline" tex="{\mathbb{T}}" text="T" xml:id="S1.p8.m6">
          <XMath>
            <XMTok font="blackboard" role="UNKNOWN">T</XMTok>
          </XMath>
        </Math> for every <Math mode="inline" tex="\theta\in{\mathbb{R}}\setminus{\mathbb{Z}}" text="theta element-of R set-minus Z" xml:id="S1.p8.m7">
          <XMath>
            <XMApp>
              <XMTok meaning="element-of" name="in" role="RELOP">∈</XMTok>
              <XMTok font="italic" name="theta" role="UNKNOWN">θ</XMTok>
              <XMApp>
                <XMTok meaning="set-minus" name="setminus" role="ADDOP">∖</XMTok>
                <XMTok font="blackboard" role="UNKNOWN">R</XMTok>
                <XMTok font="blackboard" role="UNKNOWN">Z</XMTok>
              </XMApp>
            </XMApp>
          </XMath>
        </Math>,


where <Math mode="inline" tex="{\mathbb{T}}" text="T" xml:id="S1.p8.m8">
          <XMath>
            <XMTok font="blackboard" role="UNKNOWN">T</XMTok>
          </XMath>
        </Math> denotes as usual the unit circle in <Math mode="inline" tex="{\mathbb{C}}" text="C" xml:id="S1.p8.m9">
          <XMath>
            <XMTok font="blackboard" role="UNKNOWN">C</XMTok>
          </XMath>
        </Math>.
As observed just above, it is in this case straightforward to show that <Math mode="inline" tex="\{n_{k}\,;\,k\geq 1\}" text="set@(list@(n _ k, k) &gt;= 1)" xml:id="S1.p8.m10">
          <XMath>
            <XMDual>
              <XMApp>
                <XMTok meaning="set"/>
                <XMRef idref="S1.p8.m10.2"/>
              </XMApp>
              <XMWrap>
                <XMTok role="OPEN" stretchy="false">{</XMTok>
                <XMApp xml:id="S1.p8.m10.2">
                  <XMTok meaning="greater-than-or-equals" name="geq" role="RELOP">≥</XMTok>
                  <XMDual>
                    <XMApp>
                      <XMTok meaning="list"/>
                      <XMRef idref="S1.p8.m10.2.1"/>
                      <XMRef idref="S1.p8.m10.1"/>
                    </XMApp>
                    <XMWrap>
                      <XMApp rpadding="1.7pt" xml:id="S1.p8.m10.2.1">
                        <XMTok role="SUBSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post2"/>
                        <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">n</XMTok>
                        <XMTok font="italic" fontsize="70%" role="UNKNOWN">k</XMTok>
                      </XMApp>
                      <XMTok role="PUNCT" rpadding="1.7pt">;</XMTok>
                      <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN" xml:id="S1.p8.m10.1">k</XMTok>
                    </XMWrap>
                  </XMDual>
                  <XMTok meaning="1" role="NUMBER">1</XMTok>
                </XMApp>
                <XMTok role="CLOSE" stretchy="false">}</XMTok>
              </XMWrap>
            </XMDual>
          </XMath>
        </Math> is a Kazhdan set in <Math mode="inline" tex="{\mathbb{Z}}" text="Z" xml:id="S1.p8.m11">
          <XMath>
            <XMTok font="blackboard" role="UNKNOWN">Z</XMTok>
          </XMath>
        </Math>.
<!--  %**** String Line 200 **** -->Now, it is in many settings much more convenient and natural to consider the weaker equidistribution condition that <Math mode="inline" tex="(e^{2i\pi\theta n_{k}})_{k\geq 1}" text="(e ^ (2 * i * pi * theta * n _ k)) _ (k &gt;= 1)" xml:id="S1.p8.m12">
          <XMath>
            <XMApp>
              <XMTok role="SUBSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post2"/>
              <XMDual>
                <XMRef idref="S1.p8.m12.1"/>
                <XMWrap>
                  <XMTok role="OPEN" stretchy="false">(</XMTok>
                  <XMApp xml:id="S1.p8.m12.1">
                    <XMTok role="SUPERSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post2"/>
                    <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">e</XMTok>
                    <XMApp>
                      <XMTok meaning="times" role="MULOP">⁢</XMTok>

                      <XMTok font="italic" fontsize="70%" name="pi" role="UNKNOWN">π</XMTok>
                      <XMTok font="italic" fontsize="70%" name="theta" role="UNKNOWN">θ</XMTok>
                      <XMApp>
                        <XMTok role="SUBSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post3"/>
                        <XMTok font="italic" fontsize="70%" role="UNKNOWN">n</XMTok>
                        <XMTok font="italic" fontsize="50%" role="UNKNOWN">k</XMTok>
                      </XMApp>
                    </XMApp>
                  </XMApp>
                  <XMTok role="CLOSE" stretchy="false">)</XMTok>
                </XMWrap>
              </XMDual>
              <XMApp>
                <XMTok fontsize="70%" meaning="greater-than-or-equals" name="geq" role="RELOP">≥</XMTok>
                <XMTok font="italic" fontsize="70%" role="UNKNOWN">k</XMTok>
                <XMTok fontsize="70%" meaning="1" role="NUMBER">1</XMTok>
              </XMApp>
            </XMApp>
          </XMath>
        </Math> is uniformly distributed in <Math mode="inline" tex="{\mathbb{T}}" text="T" xml:id="S1.p8.m13">
          <XMath>
            <XMTok font="blackboard" role="UNKNOWN">T</XMTok>
          </XMath>
        </Math> for every <Math mode="inline" tex="\theta\in{\mathbb{R}}\setminus{\mathbb{Q}}" text="theta element-of R set-minus Q" xml:id="S1.p8.m14">
          <XMath>
            <XMApp>
              <XMTok meaning="element-of" name="in" role="RELOP">∈</XMTok>
              <XMTok font="italic" name="theta" role="UNKNOWN">θ</XMTok>
              <XMApp>
                <XMTok meaning="set-minus" name="setminus" role="ADDOP">∖</XMTok>
                <XMTok font="blackboard" role="UNKNOWN">R</XMTok>
                <XMTok font="blackboard" role="UNKNOWN">Q</XMTok>
              </XMApp>
            </XMApp>
          </XMath>
        </Math>: this is the condition which appears in
Shalom’s Question <ref labelref="LABEL:Question_0"/>.
It is of course a weaker requirement on <Math mode="inline" tex="(n_{k})_{k\geq 1}" text="n _ k _ (k &gt;= 1)" xml:id="S1.p8.m15">
          <XMath>
            <XMApp>
              <XMTok role="SUBSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post2"/>
              <XMDual>
                <XMRef idref="S1.p8.m15.1"/>
                <XMWrap>
                  <XMTok role="OPEN" stretchy="false">(</XMTok>
                  <XMApp xml:id="S1.p8.m15.1">
                    <XMTok role="SUBSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post2"/>
                    <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">n</XMTok>
                    <XMTok font="italic" fontsize="70%" role="UNKNOWN">k</XMTok>
                  </XMApp>
                  <XMTok role="CLOSE" stretchy="false">)</XMTok>
                </XMWrap>
              </XMDual>
              <XMApp>
                <XMTok fontsize="70%" meaning="greater-than-or-equals" name="geq" role="RELOP">≥</XMTok>
                <XMTok font="italic" fontsize="70%" role="UNKNOWN">k</XMTok>
                <XMTok fontsize="70%" meaning="1" role="NUMBER">1</XMTok>
              </XMApp>
            </XMApp>
          </XMath>
        </Math> than that of being Hartman uniformly distributed, and
the sequence <Math mode="inline" tex="(n_{k})_{k\geq 1}" text="n _ k _ (k &gt;= 1)" xml:id="S1.p8.m16">
          <XMath>
            <XMApp>
              <XMTok role="SUBSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post2"/>
              <XMDual>
                <XMRef idref="S1.p8.m16.1"/>
                <XMWrap>
                  <XMTok role="OPEN" stretchy="false">(</XMTok>
                  <XMApp xml:id="S1.p8.m16.1">
                    <XMTok role="SUBSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post2"/>
                    <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">n</XMTok>
                    <XMTok font="italic" fontsize="70%" role="UNKNOWN">k</XMTok>
                  </XMApp>
                  <XMTok role="CLOSE" stretchy="false">)</XMTok>
                </XMWrap>
              </XMDual>
              <XMApp>
                <XMTok fontsize="70%" meaning="greater-than-or-equals" name="geq" role="RELOP">≥</XMTok>
                <XMTok font="italic" fontsize="70%" role="UNKNOWN">k</XMTok>
                <XMTok fontsize="70%" meaning="1" role="NUMBER">1</XMTok>
              </XMApp>
            </XMApp>
          </XMath>
        </Math> given by <Math mode="inline" tex="n_{k}=k^{2}" text="n _ k = k ^ 2" xml:id="S1.p8.m17">
          <XMath>
            <XMApp>
              <XMTok meaning="equals" role="RELOP">=</XMTok>
              <XMApp>
                <XMTok role="SUBSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post2"/>
                <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">n</XMTok>
                <XMTok font="italic" fontsize="70%" role="UNKNOWN">k</XMTok>
              </XMApp>
              <XMApp>
                <XMTok role="SUPERSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post2"/>
                <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">k</XMTok>
                <XMTok fontsize="70%" meaning="2" role="NUMBER">2</XMTok>
              </XMApp>
            </XMApp>
          </XMath>
        </Math> verifies the equidistribution
condition of Question <ref labelref="LABEL:Question_0"/> although it is not Hartman uniformly distributed in <Math mode="inline" tex="{\mathbb{Z}}" text="Z" xml:id="S1.p8.m18">
          <XMath>
            <XMTok font="blackboard" role="UNKNOWN">Z</XMTok>
          </XMath>
        </Math>.</p>
    </para>
    <para xml:id="S1.p9">
      <p>We will consider in this paper a natural extension to general locally compact groups <Math mode="inline" tex="G" text="G" xml:id="S1.p9.m1">
          <XMath>
            <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">G</XMTok>
          </XMath>
        </Math> of
the equidistribution condition of
Question <ref labelref="LABEL:Question_0"/>:
if <Math mode="inline" tex="(g_{k})_{k\geq 1}" text="g _ k _ (k &gt;= 1)" xml:id="S1.p9.m2">
          <XMath>
            <XMApp>
              <XMTok role="SUBSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post2"/>
              <XMDual>
                <XMRef idref="S1.p9.m2.1"/>
                <XMWrap>
                  <XMTok role="OPEN" stretchy="false">(</XMTok>
                  <XMApp xml:id="S1.p9.m2.1">
                    <XMTok role="SUBSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post2"/>
                    <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">g</XMTok>
                    <XMTok font="italic" fontsize="70%" role="UNKNOWN">k</XMTok>
                  </XMApp>
                  <XMTok role="CLOSE" stretchy="false">)</XMTok>
                </XMWrap>
              </XMDual>
              <XMApp>
                <XMTok fontsize="70%" meaning="greater-than-or-equals" name="geq" role="RELOP">≥</XMTok>
                <XMTok font="italic" fontsize="70%" role="UNKNOWN">k</XMTok>
                <XMTok fontsize="70%" meaning="1" role="NUMBER">1</XMTok>
              </XMApp>
            </XMApp>
          </XMath>
        </Math> is a sequence of elements of <Math mode="inline" tex="G" text="G" xml:id="S1.p9.m3">
          <XMath>
            <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">G</XMTok>
          </XMath>
        </Math>, we require the means (<ref labelref="LABEL:means"/>) to converge for all finite dimensional unitary representations of <Math mode="inline" tex="G" text="G" xml:id="S1.p9.m4">
          <XMath>
            <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">G</XMTok>
          </XMath>
        </Math> except at most countably many.
In the case of the group <Math mode="inline" tex="{\mathbb{Z}}" text="Z" xml:id="S1.p9.m5">
          <XMath>
            <XMTok font="blackboard" role="UNKNOWN">Z</XMTok>
          </XMath>
        </Math>, sequences <Math mode="inline" tex="(n_{k})_{k\geq 1}" text="n _ k _ (k &gt;= 1)" xml:id="S1.p9.m6">
          <XMath>
            <XMApp>
              <XMTok role="SUBSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post2"/>
              <XMDual>
                <XMRef idref="S1.p9.m6.1"/>
                <XMWrap>
                  <XMTok role="OPEN" stretchy="false">(</XMTok>
                  <XMApp xml:id="S1.p9.m6.1">
                    <XMTok role="SUBSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post2"/>
                    <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">n</XMTok>
                    <XMTok font="italic" fontsize="70%" role="UNKNOWN">k</XMTok>
                  </XMApp>
                  <XMTok role="CLOSE" stretchy="false">)</XMTok>
                </XMWrap>
              </XMDual>
              <XMApp>
                <XMTok fontsize="70%" meaning="greater-than-or-equals" name="geq" role="RELOP">≥</XMTok>
                <XMTok font="italic" fontsize="70%" role="UNKNOWN">k</XMTok>
                <XMTok fontsize="70%" meaning="1" role="NUMBER">1</XMTok>
              </XMApp>
            </XMApp>
          </XMath>
        </Math> of integers such that <Math mode="inline" tex="(e^{2i\pi\theta n_{k}})_{k\geq 1}" text="(e ^ (2 * i * pi * theta * n _ k)) _ (k &gt;= 1)" xml:id="S1.p9.m7">
          <XMath>
            <XMApp>
              <XMTok role="SUBSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post2"/>
              <XMDual>
                <XMRef idref="S1.p9.m7.1"/>
                <XMWrap>
                  <XMTok role="OPEN" stretchy="false">(</XMTok>
                  <XMApp xml:id="S1.p9.m7.1">
                    <XMTok role="SUPERSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post2"/>
                    <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">e</XMTok>
                    <XMApp>
                      <XMTok meaning="times" role="MULOP">⁢</XMTok>
                      <XMTok fontsize="70%" meaning="2" role="NUMBER">2</XMTok>
                      <XMTok font="italic" fontsize="70%" role="UNKNOWN">i</XMTok>
                      <XMTok font="italic" fontsize="70%" name="pi" role="UNKNOWN">π</XMTok>
                      <XMTok font="italic" fontsize="70%" name="theta" role="UNKNOWN">θ</XMTok>
                      <XMApp>
                        <XMTok role="SUBSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post3"/>
                        <XMTok font="italic" fontsize="70%" role="UNKNOWN">n</XMTok>
                        <XMTok font="italic" fontsize="50%" role="UNKNOWN">k</XMTok>
                      </XMApp>
                    </XMApp>
                  </XMApp>
                  <XMTok role="CLOSE" stretchy="false">)</XMTok>
                </XMWrap>
              </XMDual>
              <XMApp>
                <XMTok fontsize="70%" meaning="greater-than-or-equals" name="geq" role="RELOP">≥</XMTok>
                <XMTok font="italic" fontsize="70%" role="UNKNOWN">k</XMTok>
                <XMTok fontsize="70%" meaning="1" role="NUMBER">1</XMTok>
              </XMApp>
            </XMApp>
          </XMath>
        </Math> is uniformly distributed in <Math mode="inline" tex="{\mathbb{T}}" text="T" xml:id="S1.p9.m8">
          <XMath>
            <XMTok font="blackboard" role="UNKNOWN">T</XMTok>
          </XMath>
        </Math> for all <Math mode="inline" tex="\theta\in{\mathbb{R}}" text="theta element-of R" xml:id="S1.p9.m9">
          <XMath>
            <XMApp>
              <XMTok meaning="element-of" name="in" role="RELOP">∈</XMTok>
              <XMTok font="italic" name="theta" role="UNKNOWN">θ</XMTok>
              <XMTok font="blackboard" role="UNKNOWN">R</XMTok>
            </XMApp>
          </XMath>
        </Math> except countably many are
said to be of first kind (see for instance <cite class="ltx_citemacro_cite">[<bibref bibrefs="Ha2" separator="," yyseparator=","/>]</cite>).
The generalization of Question <ref labelref="LABEL:Question_1"/>
to this setting runs as follows:</p>
    </para>
    <theorem class="ltx_theorem_question" inlist="thm theorem:question" labels="LABEL:Question_1.3" xml:id="S1.Thmtheorem4">
      <tags>
        <tag>Question 1.4</tag>
        <tag role="autoref">1.4</tag>
        <tag role="refnum">1.4</tag>
        <tag role="typerefnum">Question 1.4</tag>
      </tags>
      <title class="ltx_runin"><tag><text font="bold">Question 1.4</text></tag></title>
      <para xml:id="S1.Thmtheorem4.p1">
        <p><text font="italic">Let <Math mode="inline" tex="(g_{k})_{k\geq 1}" text="g _ k _ (k &gt;= 1)" xml:id="S1.Thmtheorem4.p1.m1">
              <XMath>
                <XMApp>
                  <XMTok role="SUBSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post3"/>
                  <XMDual>
                    <XMRef idref="S1.Thmtheorem4.p1.m1.1"/>
                    <XMWrap>
                      <XMTok font="upright" role="OPEN" stretchy="false">(</XMTok>
                      <XMApp xml:id="S1.Thmtheorem4.p1.m1.1">
                        <XMTok role="SUBSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post3"/>
                        <XMTok role="UNKNOWN">g</XMTok>
                        <XMTok fontsize="70%" role="UNKNOWN">k</XMTok>
                      </XMApp>
                      <XMTok font="upright" role="CLOSE" stretchy="false">)</XMTok>
                    </XMWrap>
                  </XMDual>
                  <XMApp>
                    <XMTok font="upright" fontsize="70%" meaning="greater-than-or-equals" name="geq" role="RELOP">≥</XMTok>
                    <XMTok fontsize="70%" role="UNKNOWN">k</XMTok>
                    <XMTok font="upright" fontsize="70%" meaning="1" role="NUMBER">1</XMTok>
                  </XMApp>
                </XMApp>
              </XMath>
            </Math> be a sequence of elements of a
locally compact group <Math mode="inline" tex="G" text="G" xml:id="S1.Thmtheorem4.p1.m2">
              <XMath>
                <XMTok role="UNKNOWN">G</XMTok>
              </XMath>
            </Math> which
satisfies the following equidistribution property:</text></p>
      </para>
      <para xml:id="S1.Thmtheorem4.p2">
        <equation labels="LABEL:equi1" xml:id="S1.E2">
          <tags>
            <tag>(2)</tag>
            <tag role="autoref"><text font="italic">Equation 2</text></tag>
            <tag role="refnum">2</tag>
          </tags>
          <inline-para class="ltx_markedasmath ltx_minipage" vattach="middle" width="369.9pt">
            <para xml:id="S1.E2.m1.p1">
              <p><text font="italic">for all finite dimensional irreducible unitary
representations </text><Math mode="inline" tex="\pi" text="pi" xml:id="S1.E2.m1.p1.m1">
                  <XMath>
                    <XMTok font="italic" name="pi" role="UNKNOWN">π</XMTok>
                  </XMath>
                </Math><text font="italic"> of </text><Math mode="inline" tex="G" text="G" xml:id="S1.E2.m1.p1.m2">
                  <XMath>
                    <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">G</XMTok>
                  </XMath>
                </Math><text font="italic"> on a Hilbert space </text><Math mode="inline" tex="H" text="H" xml:id="S1.E2.m1.p1.m3">
                  <XMath>
                    <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">H</XMTok>
                  </XMath>
                </Math><text font="italic">, except at most countably many,</text></p>
              <equation xml:id="S1.Ex1">
                <Math mode="display" tex="\xymatrix@C=50pt{\dfrac{1}{N}{\displaystyle}\sum_{k=1}^{N}{{\langle{\pi(g_{k})%&#10;x},{y}\rangle}}\ar[r]_{-}{\smash[b]{\xymatrix@C=13pt{\scriptstyle N\ar[r]&amp;%&#10;\scriptstyle+\infty}}}&amp;0}\quad\textrm{for every}\ x,y\in H." text="formulae@([\xymatrix] * @ * C = list@(50 * p * t * (1 / N) * ((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ N)@(list@(pi * g _ k * x, y) * [\ar] * (delimited-[]@(r)) _ - * [\xymatrix] * [@C=13ptN\ar[r]&amp;+] * infinity * &amp; * 0), [for every] * x), y element-of H)" xml:id="S1.Ex1.m1">
                  <XMath>
                    <XMDual>
                      <XMRef idref="S1.Ex1.m1.3"/>

                                          </XMApp>
                                        </XMApp>
                                        <XMTok font="italic" fontsize="70%" role="UNKNOWN">N</XMTok>
                                      </XMApp>
                                      <XMApp>

                                        <XMTok role="UNKNOWN">&amp;</XMTok>

                                    </XMApp>
                                  </XMApp>
                                  <XMTok font="italic" name="quad" role="PUNCT"> </XMTok>
                                  <XMApp xml:id="S1.Ex1.m1.3.1.2">
                                    <XMTok meaning="times" role="MULOP">⁢</XMTok>
                                    <XMText rpadding="5.0pt"><text font="italic">for every</text></XMText>
                                    <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">x</XMTok>
                                  </XMApp>
                                </XMWrap>
                              </XMDual>
                            </XMApp>
                            <XMTok role="PUNCT">,</XMTok>
                            <XMApp xml:id="S1.Ex1.m1.3.2">
                              <XMTok meaning="element-of" name="in" role="RELOP">∈</XMTok>
                              <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">y</XMTok>
                              <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">H</XMTok>
                            </XMApp>
                          </XMWrap>
                        </XMDual>
                        <XMTok role="PERIOD">.</XMTok>
                      </XMWrap>
                    </XMDual>
                  </XMath>
                </Math>
              </equation>
            </para>
          </inline-para>
        </equation>
        <p><text font="italic">When is it true that <Math mode="inline" tex="Q=\{g_{k}\,;\,k\geq 1\}" xml:id="S1.Thmtheorem4.p2.m1">
              <XMath>
                <XMTok role="UNKNOWN">Q</XMTok>
                <XMTok font="upright" meaning="equals" role="RELOP">=</XMTok>
                <XMWrap>
                  <XMTok font="upright" role="OPEN" stretchy="false">{</XMTok>
                  <XMApp rpadding="1.7pt">
                    <XMTok role="SUBSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post3"/>
                    <XMTok role="UNKNOWN">g</XMTok>
                    <XMTok fontsize="70%" role="UNKNOWN">k</XMTok>
                  </XMApp>
                  <XMTok font="upright" role="PUNCT" rpadding="1.7pt">;</XMTok>
                  <XMTok role="UNKNOWN" xml:id="S1.Thmtheorem4.p2.m1.1">k</XMTok>
                  <XMTok font="upright" meaning="greater-than-or-equals" name="geq" role="RELOP">≥</XMTok>
                  <XMTok font="upright" meaning="1" role="NUMBER">1</XMTok>
                  <XMTok font="upright" role="CLOSE" stretchy="false">}</XMTok>
                </XMWrap>
              </XMath>
            </Math> is a Kazhdan set in <Math mode="inline" tex="G" text="G" xml:id="S1.Thmtheorem4.p2.m2">
              <XMath>
                <XMTok role="UNKNOWN">G</XMTok>
              </XMath>
            </Math>?</text></p>
      </para>
    </theorem>
    <para xml:id="S1.p10">
      <p>We provide in this work an answer to Question <ref labelref="LABEL:Question_1.3"/>
when <Math mode="inline" tex="G" text="G" xml:id="S1.p10.m1">
          <XMath>
            <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">G</XMTok>
          </XMath>
        </Math> is a second countable Moore group, and thus fully answer Shalom’s Question <ref labelref="LABEL:Question_0"/> as well. We also answer
Question <ref labelref="LABEL:Question_00"/> by
giving a complete description of Kazhdan sets in many classic groups which do not have Property (T), including the groups <Math mode="inline" tex="{\mathbb{Z}}^{k}" text="Z ^ k" xml:id="S1.p10.m2">
          <XMath>
            <XMApp>
              <XMTok role="SUPERSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post2"/>
              <XMTok font="blackboard" role="UNKNOWN">Z</XMTok>
              <XMTok font="italic" fontsize="70%" role="UNKNOWN">k</XMTok>
            </XMApp>
          </XMath>
        </Math> and <Math mode="inline" tex="{\mathbb{R}}^{k}" text="R ^ k" xml:id="S1.p10.m3">
          <XMath>
            <XMApp>
              <XMTok role="SUPERSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post2"/>
              <XMTok font="blackboard" role="UNKNOWN">R</XMTok>
              <XMTok font="italic" fontsize="70%" role="UNKNOWN">k</XMTok>
            </XMApp>
          </XMath>
        </Math>, <Math mode="inline" tex="k\geq 1" text="k &gt;= 1" xml:id="S1.p10.m4">
          <XMath>
            <XMApp>
              <XMTok meaning="greater-than-or-equals" name="geq" role="RELOP">≥</XMTok>
              <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">k</XMTok>
              <XMTok meaning="1" role="NUMBER">1</XMTok>
            </XMApp>
          </XMath>
        </Math>, and the Heisenberg groups of all dimensions.
Let us now describe our main results in more detail.</p>
    </para>
  </section>
  <section inlist="toc" labels="LABEL:Sec2" xml:id="S2">
    <tags>
      <tag>2</tag>
      <tag role="autoref">section 2</tag>
      <tag role="refnum">2</tag>
      <tag role="typerefnum">§2</tag>
    </tags>
    <title><tag close=" ">2</tag>Main results</title>
    <para xml:id="S2.p1">
      <p>We first briefly set down some notation and recall some important definitions.</p>
    </para>
    <subsection inlist="toc" xml:id="S2.SS1">
      <tags>
        <tag>2.1</tag>
        <tag role="autoref">subsection 2.1</tag>
        <tag role="refnum">2.1</tag>
        <tag role="typerefnum">§2.1</tag>
      </tags>
      <title><tag close=" ">2.1</tag>Definitions and notation</title>
      <para xml:id="S2.SS1.p1">
        <p>The Hilbert spaces will always be supposed in this paper to be complex,
and endowed with an inner product <Math mode="inline" tex="{{\langle{\,\cdot\,},{\cdot\,}\rangle}}" text="list@(cdot, cdot)" xml:id="S2.SS1.p1.m1">
            <XMath>
              <XMDual>
                <XMApp>
                  <XMTok meaning="list"/>
                  <XMRef idref="S2.SS1.p1.m1.1"/>
                  <XMRef idref="S2.SS1.p1.m1.2"/>
                </XMApp>
                <XMWrap>
                  <XMTok name="langle" role="OPEN" rpadding="1.7pt" stretchy="false">⟨</XMTok>
                  <XMTok name="cdot" role="MULOP" rpadding="1.7pt" xml:id="S2.SS1.p1.m1.1">⋅</XMTok>
                  <XMTok role="PUNCT">,</XMTok>
                  <XMTok name="cdot" role="MULOP" rpadding="1.7pt" xml:id="S2.SS1.p1.m1.2">⋅</XMTok>
                  <XMTok name="rangle" role="CLOSE" stretchy="false">⟩</XMTok>
                </XMWrap>
              </XMDual>
            </XMath>
          </Math>
which is linear in the first variable and antilinear in the second
variable. A <text class="ltx_emph" font="italic">unitary representation</text> of <Math mode="inline" tex="G" text="G" xml:id="S2.SS1.p1.m2">
            <XMath>
              <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">G</XMTok>
            </XMath>
          </Math> on <Math mode="inline" tex="H" text="H" xml:id="S2.SS1.p1.m3">
            <XMath>
              <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">H</XMTok>
            </XMath>
          </Math> is a group
morphism
from
<Math mode="inline" tex="G" text="G" xml:id="S2.SS1.p1.m4">
            <XMath>
              <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">G</XMTok>
            </XMath>
          </Math> into the group <Math mode="inline" tex="{\mathscr{U}}(H)" text="U * H" xml:id="S2.SS1.p1.m5">
            <XMath>
              <XMApp>
                <XMTok meaning="times" role="MULOP">⁢</XMTok>
                <XMTok font="script" role="UNKNOWN">U</XMTok>
                <XMDual>
                  <XMRef idref="S2.SS1.p1.m5.1"/>
                  <XMWrap>
                    <XMTok role="OPEN" stretchy="false">(</XMTok>
                    <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN" xml:id="S2.SS1.p1.m5.1">H</XMTok>
                    <XMTok role="CLOSE" stretchy="false">)</XMTok>
                  </XMWrap>
                </XMDual>
              </XMApp>
            </XMath>
          </Math> of all unitary operators on <Math mode="inline" tex="H" text="H" xml:id="S2.SS1.p1.m6">
            <XMath>
              <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">H</XMTok>
            </XMath>
          </Math> which
is strongly continuous, i. e. such that the map
<!--  %**** String Line 250 **** --><Math mode="inline" tex="\smash{\xymatrix{g\ar@{|-&gt;}[r]&amp;\pi(g)x}}" text="[\xymatrix] * g * [\ar] * @ * ket@(-) * delimited-[]@(r) * &amp; * pi * g * x" xml:id="S2.SS1.p1.m7">
            <XMath>
              <XMApp>
                <XMTok meaning="times" role="MULOP">⁢</XMTok>
                <ERROR class="undefined">\xymatrix</ERROR>
                <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">g</XMTok>
                <ERROR class="undefined">\ar</ERROR>
                <XMTok role="UNKNOWN">@</XMTok>
                <XMDual>
                  <XMApp>
                    <XMTok meaning="ket"/>
                    <XMRef idref="S2.SS1.p1.m7.1"/>
                  </XMApp>
                  <XMWrap>
                    <XMTok role="OPEN" stretchy="false">|</XMTok>
                    <XMTok meaning="minus" role="ADDOP" xml:id="S2.SS1.p1.m7.1">-</XMTok>
                    <XMTok meaning="greater-than" role="CLOSE">&gt;</XMTok>
                  </XMWrap>
                </XMDual>
                <XMDual>
                  <XMApp>
                    <XMTok meaning="delimited-[]"/>
                    <XMRef idref="S2.SS1.p1.m7.2"/>
                  </XMApp>
                  <XMWrap>
                    <XMTok role="OPEN" stretchy="false">[</XMTok>
                    <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN" xml:id="S2.SS1.p1.m7.2">r</XMTok>
                    <XMTok role="CLOSE" stretchy="false">]</XMTok>
                  </XMWrap>
                </XMDual>
                <XMTok role="UNKNOWN">&amp;</XMTok>
                <XMTok font="italic" name="pi" role="UNKNOWN">π</XMTok>
                <XMDual>
                  <XMRef idref="S2.SS1.p1.m7.3"/>
                  <XMWrap>
                    <XMTok role="OPEN" stretchy="false">(</XMTok>
                    <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN" xml:id="S2.SS1.p1.m7.3">g</XMTok>
                    <XMTok role="CLOSE" stretchy="false">)</XMTok>
                  </XMWrap>
                </XMDual>
                <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">x</XMTok>
              </XMApp>
            </XMath>
          </Math> is continuous from <Math mode="inline" tex="G" text="G" xml:id="S2.SS1.p1.m8">
            <XMath>
              <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">G</XMTok>
            </XMath>
          </Math> into
<Math mode="inline" tex="H" text="H" xml:id="S2.SS1.p1.m9">
            <XMath>
              <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">H</XMTok>
            </XMath>
          </Math> for all vectors <Math mode="inline" tex="x\in H" text="x element-of H" xml:id="S2.SS1.p1.m10">
            <XMath>
              <XMApp>
                <XMTok meaning="element-of" name="in" role="RELOP">∈</XMTok>
                <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">x</XMTok>
                <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">H</XMTok>
              </XMApp>
            </XMath>
          </Math>. As all the representations we consider
in this paper are unitary, we will often drop the word “unitary” and
speak simply of representations of a group <Math mode="inline" tex="G" text="G" xml:id="S2.SS1.p1.m11">
            <XMath>
              <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">G</XMTok>
            </XMath>
          </Math> on a Hilbert space <Math mode="inline" tex="H" text="H" xml:id="S2.SS1.p1.m12">
            <XMath>
              <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">H</XMTok>
            </XMath>
          </Math>.</p>
      </para>
      <theorem class="ltx_theorem_definition" inlist="thm theorem:definition" labels="LABEL:Definition_1" xml:id="S2.Thmtheorem1">
        <tags>
          <tag>Definition 2.1</tag>
          <tag role="autoref">2.1</tag>
          <tag role="refnum">2.1</tag>
          <tag role="typerefnum">Definition 2.1</tag>
        </tags>
        <title class="ltx_runin"><tag><text font="bold">Definition 2.1</text></tag></title>
        <para xml:id="S2.Thmtheorem1.p1">
          <p class="ltx_emph"><text font="italic">Let <Math mode="inline" tex="{Q}" text="Q" xml:id="S2.Thmtheorem1.p1.m1">
                <XMath>
                  <XMTok role="UNKNOWN">Q</XMTok>
                </XMath>
              </Math> be a subset of a topological group <Math mode="inline" tex="G" text="G" xml:id="S2.Thmtheorem1.p1.m2">
                <XMath>
                  <XMTok role="UNKNOWN">G</XMTok>
                </XMath>
              </Math>, <Math mode="inline" tex="\varepsilon" text="varepsilon" xml:id="S2.Thmtheorem1.p1.m3">
                <XMath>
                  <XMTok name="varepsilon" role="UNKNOWN">ε</XMTok>
                </XMath>
              </Math> a
positive
real number, and <Math mode="inline" tex="\pi" text="pi" xml:id="S2.Thmtheorem1.p1.m4">
                <XMath>
                  <XMTok name="pi" role="UNKNOWN">π</XMTok>
                </XMath>
              </Math> a unitary
representation of <Math mode="inline" tex="G" text="G" xml:id="S2.Thmtheorem1.p1.m5">
                <XMath>
                  <XMTok role="UNKNOWN">G</XMTok>
                </XMath>
              </Math> on a Hilbert space <Math mode="inline" tex="H" text="H" xml:id="S2.Thmtheorem1.p1.m6">
                <XMath>
                  <XMTok role="UNKNOWN">H</XMTok>
                </XMath>
              </Math>. A vector <Math mode="inline" tex="x\in H" text="x element-of H" xml:id="S2.Thmtheorem1.p1.m7">
                <XMath>
                  <XMApp>
                    <XMTok font="upright" meaning="element-of" name="in" role="RELOP">∈</XMTok>
                    <XMTok role="UNKNOWN">x</XMTok>
                    <XMTok role="UNKNOWN">H</XMTok>
                  </XMApp>
                </XMath>
              </Math> is said to be
<Math mode="inline" tex="(Q,\varepsilon)" text="open-interval@(Q, varepsilon)" xml:id="S2.Thmtheorem1.p1.m8">
                <XMath>
                  <XMDual>
                    <XMApp>
                      <XMTok meaning="open-interval"/>
                      <XMRef idref="S2.Thmtheorem1.p1.m8.1"/>
                      <XMRef idref="S2.Thmtheorem1.p1.m8.2"/>
                    </XMApp>
                    <XMWrap>
                      <XMTok font="upright" role="OPEN" stretchy="false">(</XMTok>
                      <XMTok role="UNKNOWN" xml:id="S2.Thmtheorem1.p1.m8.1">Q</XMTok>
                      <XMTok font="upright" role="PUNCT">,</XMTok>
                      <XMTok name="varepsilon" role="UNKNOWN" xml:id="S2.Thmtheorem1.p1.m8.2">ε</XMTok>
                      <XMTok font="upright" role="CLOSE" stretchy="false">)</XMTok>
                    </XMWrap>
                  </XMDual>
                </XMath>
              </Math></text>-invariant for <Math mode="inline" tex="\pi" text="pi" xml:id="S2.Thmtheorem1.p1.m9">
              <XMath>
                <XMTok font="italic" name="pi" role="UNKNOWN">π</XMTok>
              </XMath>
            </Math><text font="italic"> if</text></p>
          <equation xml:id="S2.Ex2">
            <Math mode="display" tex="\sup_{g\,\in{Q}}||\pi(g)x-x||&lt;\varepsilon||x||." text="(supremum _ (g element-of Q))@(norm@(pi * g * x - x)) less varepsilon * norm@(x)" xml:id="S2.Ex2.m1">
              <XMath>
                <XMDual>
                  <XMRef idref="S2.Ex2.m1.4"/>
                  <XMWrap>
                    <XMApp xml:id="S2.Ex2.m1.4">
                      <XMTok meaning="less-than" role="RELOP">&lt;</XMTok>
                      <XMApp>
                        <XMApp scriptpos="mid">

                          <XMTok meaning="supremum" role="LIMITOP" scriptpos="mid">sup</XMTok>
                          <XMApp>
                            <XMTok fontsize="70%" meaning="element-of" name="in" role="RELOP">∈</XMTok>
                            <XMTok font="italic" fontsize="70%" role="UNKNOWN" rpadding="1.7pt">g</XMTok>
                            <XMTok font="italic" fontsize="70%" role="UNKNOWN">Q</XMTok>
                          </XMApp>
                        </XMApp>
                        <XMDual>
                          <XMApp>
                            <XMTok meaning="norm"/>
                            <XMRef idref="S2.Ex2.m1.4.1"/>
